item.title: Creating a Weekly Log
item.description:
I usually keep a log of interesting things I come across for future reference (stashed in Evernote or Pocket), but there was no consistency in this. More often than now, I simply forget to maintain this log. I think it will be useful to write a weekly post for collecting such info. This will keep the motivation going and engage in a variety of interesting stuff. Also, this would enable me to write something down every week, as blog posts usually take much longer to conceive and write. I should be able to find the time to post this every Sunday.

The first post is here. All posts are tagged log, so you can check the entire list here.

item.title: Who Watches the Watchmen?
item.description:
I read my first graphic novel and couldn’t resist writing a review for it.

Watchmen by Alan Moore
My rating: 5 of 5 stars

Who watches the watchmen?
My first book from the graphic novel genre, and I seemed to have picked up the best. The artwork captivates you from page 1; perfectly portrays the grim darkness of the cold-war era New York city, dingy, drab, filled with an aura of cynicism and the palpable tension from an impending nuclear holocaust. Moore’s characterization of these heroes is intricate, it breaks away from the run-of-the-mill superhero BS of noble ideologies and unicorn sentiments. Here, it’s realistic… grisly – “Existence is random. Has no pattern save what we imagine after staring at it for too long. No meaning save what we choose to impose. This rudderless world is not shaped by vague metaphysical forces”.
This novel is only a stone’s throw away from being a pure work of psychological realism. Shows why a story about a bunch of superheros needn’t always suck (ahem, Marvel!).

View all my reviews

item.title: About
item.description:
• I live in New York City. Am terrified of the possibility of falling asleep on a subway.
  • I enjoy working with learning algorithms, all the while controlling my paranoia that computers would get smarter than me someday.
  • Lately, I’ve been obsessed with the elegance of Functional Programming.
  • I spend my evenings running along Hudson dreaming of owning a pretty white yatch someday. I also read books of all kind, I write reviews occasionally for the ones I really love.

item.title: Colophon
item.description:
This website is written using Emacs and compiled into HTML using Hugo - a static site generator written in Go. This template has been shamelessly built using the blog of Nishant Totla. He’d designed it based “on top of the excellent work by Prakhar Srivastav using the minimalistic CSS framework called Skeleton”. Thank you both!

Icons on the site are courtesy of Fontello. Typography uses Source Sans Pro and Open Sans.
